thread.title: 2015 boys and girls cross country
thread.title_full: 2015 boys and girls cross country preview | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Larry Rubama
title: 2015 boys and girls cross country
text:
FIVE THINGS YOU NEED TO KNOW State title or bust
Cox’s Jonathan Lomogda has his eyes set on a state title after last season’s third-place finish. He also is the defending 6A South Region and Coastal Conference champion.
Stiff competition
Princess Anne’s Doria Martingayle finished runner-up at the Group 5A state meet and won the 5A South Region and Atlantic Conference titles last season as a sophomore. But to win a state title she has to outrun George Marshall’s Heather Holt, who beat her by 22 seconds last season in the state meet.
Moving up
Kellam, which was competitive in 5A, moves up to 6A this season after another round of reclassification. It also makes Kellam senior Ryan Drew’s chances of winning a state title even tougher as he must run against Cox’s Jonathan Lomogda. Last season, Drew finished third at the 5A state meet. “If we were in 5A, Ryan would be contending for a state title,” said Kellam coach Bill Bernard. “But it’s going to be exciting with Jonathan and Ryan. Ryan is going to get better competition and it will be tougher to win a state title.”
Moving down
Great Bridge is moving from Group 5A to 4A. The move should benefit the Wildcats, who now will compete in Conference 17. Coach Bill Volkman said the Wildcats are the team to beat on paper: “The boys have worked very hard this summer and I expect all that hard work to pay off in the end. We’ll see what happens.”
Great expectations
Last season Hickory finished third at the Group 5A state meet but coach Jud Sarver is thinking bigger this season. The Hawks are led by senior Kailyn Gyuricsko and sophomore Jodi Tolarchyk. Tolarchyk last season was runner-up at the Atlantic Conference meet, sixth at the 5A South Region meet and fourth at in the state. Gyuricsko was third at conference, ninth at region and 16th at the state meet. Maddie Eason, Bela Melendez, Kate Miller, Jessica Hibler and Abbie LeFevre give the Hawks depth.
___
TOP BOYS TEAMS IN SOUTH HAMPTON ROADS
1. Ocean Lakes
The Dolphins lack a top runner but have incredible depth as 37 athletes are competing for the top five spots. “We will be led by a very equal senior foursome of Lance Sheridan, Drew Park, Ryan Schleicher and Logan Sawyer,” Ocean Lakes coach Mike Nestor said. The Dolphins have won nine Beach District or Coastal Conference titles in a row. They also are the defending 6A South Region champions.
2. Cox
The Falcons return one of the nation’s top runners in Jonathan Lomogda, who finished third at the Group 6A state meet last season. They also have junior David Scherrer, who finished seventh in the region, along with six freshmen who ran under 5:15 in the 1,600 last year.
3. Kellam
The Knights return four of their top five runners led by Ryan Drew (fourth at 5A state meet) and senior Christian McDonald, a state qualifier. And they have sophomore Jack Kirschner, senior Jonah Anderson and sophomore John Mikovitz.
4. Hickory
The Hawks are the favorites for the Atlantic Conference title because of their depth, which has been lacking in recent seasons. Leading the way is senior Jarrell Hibler, runner-up at last year’s conference meet. Others include Cameron Riedy, Tyler Lefevre, Will Gamberg, Dylan McCormick and Chad Brown.
5. Great Bridge
The Wildcats are led by senior Dayton Pack and junior Alex Belin, third and seventh, respectively, at the PenSouth Conference meet. They also welcome sophomore Johnny Chasnet, a first-year runner, and freshman Caleb Mincheff. Coach Bill Volkman thinks both have a chance to be special runners.
___
TOP GIRLS TEAMS IN SOUTH HAMPTON ROADS
1. Ocean Lakes
The Dolphins are lead by all-state candidates Rachel Boyce and junior Madeleine King. King won the 6A South Region last season and was eighth at state. They also have Ashley Cooper, Natalie Kubicki, Lauren Nery, Morgan Will, Hannah Saunders and Laura Grabarcyzk. The girls have won either the Beach District or Coastal Conference title the past seven seasons.
2. Hickory
Senior Hannah Glasgow – eighth at the 5A state meet – is injured and will not compete this season. But coach Jud Sarver thinks the Hawks will still be strong even without her. They are led by senior Kailyn Gyuricsko and sophomore Jodi Tolarchyk. Maddie Eason, Bela Melendez, Kate Miller, Jessica Hibler and Abbie LeFevre give the Hawks plenty of depth.
3. Kellam
The Knights are young and talented, led by sophomores Eileen Vedder and Taylor Jones both 5A state qualifiers and top-five finishers in the Atlantic Conference. Coach Bill Bernard predicts this will be a breakout year for both runners.
4. Princess Anne
The Cavaliers are led by junior Doria Martingayle, who last season finished runner-up at the 5A state meet. The Cavaliers will get help from sophomore Kasey Sutryk and seniors Emma Jennings and Maggie Marshall, who was runner-up at the conference meet.
5. Great Bridge
Wildcats coach Bill Volkman is excited about the upcoming season. Juniors Ally Jones and Carley Hill finished 16th and 19th, respectively, at the PenSouth Conference meet. Also watch for sophomore Abby Oliphant, who has the potential to be very good.
___
AROUND THE COURSE
Cox returns five of its top seven girls runners. Sophomore Gracen Samuel was sixth in the conference, 10th at region and 59th at state. The Falcons also have Lauren McGovern, Samantha Werve, Jeanine Seaman and Michelle Jones. ... Deep Creek has a girls team made up of soccer players who came out for conditioning. The Hornets boys will be young and inexperienced with sophomores Matthew Daniels and Zachary Patterson. ... Grassfield is led by senior Thomas Amabile, who last season he finished 11th at the 6A South Region meet and was 33rd at the 6A state meet. His goal this season is to earn all-state honors. ... Green Run coach Megan Gonzales said her top five runners are already ahead of last year’s pace. They are led by Luis Marin and Jayson Briscoe. The girls are led by Sara Wisher and Sarah Hilbert. ... Isle of Wight begins its second season of cross country. The boys are led by sophomore Chris Vaughn and the girls by sophomore Hannah Plott. ... Lakeland sophomore Ryan Wright wants to continue to improve after placing 64th at the 4A South Region meet as a freshman. ... Landstown senior Jordan Sulcer finished 27th at the 6A South Region meet. The girls are led by Maddy Ryan. The junior ran well last year but was injured in the postseason. ... Kempsville is led by junior Laura Kielbowicz, who was 12th at the conference meet last season. ... Maury is led by senior Renee Garrow, who placed seventh at the Atlantic Conference meet. Also watch for sophomores Ann Howell, Alyssa Morgan and Kaitlin Smyth, and freshman Eliza Madison. ... Norfolk Academy is led by junior Julia Lambert and freshman Emma Somers, who were 12th and 21st, respectively, at the VISAA state meet. Junior Petey Decker and senior Connor Yager lead the boys. Decker was sixth at state meet and Yager was 55th. ... Norfolk Collegiate returns its top seven runners, including Chandler Branton, Thomas Batzel, Frankie White and Harrison Fuller. Those four could help the Oaks finish in the top 10 at the VISAA Division II meet. Sophomores Maddie Foster and Claudia King lead the girls. ... The Princess Anne boys have a strong 1-2 punch with senior Harrison Martingayle and junior Josh Spare. Martingayle was runner-up at conference meet, seventh at region meet and 14th at state meet. Spare was third at conference meet. ... Tallwood ’s boys are led by senior Andrew Clark and freshman Sean Moulton. The girls are led by senior Maggie Aydlett, who was 83rd at state, and junior Heaven Gibson.
___
RECLASSIFICATIONS
Another round of realignment by the Virginia High School League has shuffled area teams for the 2015-16 school year. For the first time, South Hampton Roads public schools will be spread across four classifications – Groups 6A, 5A, 4A and 3A.
Four teams move down in classification: Booker T. Washington, Norcom, Lakeland and Phoebus move to Group 3A, while Great Bridge heads to 4A.
Kellam, meanwhile, has moved up to Group 6A and Nansemond River to Group 5A.
A look at the new conference alignment:
Group 6A
Coastal Conference: Bayside, Cox, First Colonial, Kellam, Landstown, Ocean Lakes, Tallwood
Monitor-Merrimac Conference: Granby, Grassfield, Oscar Smith, Western Branch, Woodside
Group 5A
Atlantic Conference: Green Run, Hickory, Indian River, Kempsville, Maury, Norview, Princess Anne, Salem
PenSouth Conference: Bethel, Gloucester, Hampton, Kecoughtan, Menchville, Nansemond River, Warwick
Group 4A
Conference 17: Churchland, Deep Creek, Great Bridge, King’s Fork, Lake Taylor, Wilson
Ironclad Conference: Denbigh, Grafton, Heritage, Jamestown, Lafayette, Smithfield
Group 3A
Conference 27: Booker T. Washington, Lakeland, Norcom, Phoebus, Tabb, York
Larry Rubama, 757-446-2273 or larry.rubama@pilotonline.com , Twitter: @LHRubama
 5 photos: Doria Martingayle of Princess Anne heads for a first place finish at the girls Group 5A South Region cross country championship at Bells Mill Park in Chesapeake on Wednesday, Nov. 5, 2014. (Steve Earley 5 Posted to : Sports
